{{refimprove|date=February 2011}} A '''dual-track system''' is an [[economic system]] in which the [[government]] controls key sectors of the [[economy]], while allowing [[private enterprise]] limited control over the other sectors.<ref>1981: Dual-track Price System -- China.org.cn.</ref>
In China, the government followed dual-track pricing, known as "''shuangguizhi''" in Chinese. State-controlled (planned) prices, which were lower, accompanied the market prices, which were higher. This was done to ensure stability and gradual opening of markets (instead of a "big bang" strategy of sudden transformation to capitalism that was attempted in Eastern Europe and Russia). However, to provide incentive to the State-owned Enterprises, government allowed selling of the products at market prices after the planned targets had been met.<ref>Barry Naughton, "The Chinese Economy" (MIT Press, 2007)</ref>
==See also== *[[Chinese Economic Reform]]
==References== <references/> *["1981: Dual-track Price System -- China.org.cn." China.org.cn - China News, Weather, Business, Travel & Language Courses. Web. 24 Feb. 2011. <http://www.china.org.cn/features/60years/2009-09/16/content_18534471.htm>.]
[[Category:Economic systems]]

<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Dusthole-billboard-1.jpg|thumb|400px|Clark County, Nevada Department of Air Quality & Environmental Management Campaign Billboard, 2005]] --> '''Dusty the Dusthole''' was a [[Clark County, Nevada|Clark County]] Department of Air Quality & Environmental Management mascot created 2003 in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2003/sep/25/dusty-the-dusthole-ads-begin/ |title=Dusty the Dusthole Ads Begin |publisher=The Las Vegas Sun |date=25 September 2003 |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> The character and his trademark slogan ''"Don't Be a Dusthole"'' were seen by millions of residents and tourists in the state of Nevada via a massive media push consisting of billboards, radio ads, public appearances, TV spots, and print coverage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/May-12-Wed-2004/news/23861369.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324101913/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2004/May-12-Wed-2004/news/23861369.html |title=$150,000 Ad Blitz Tries to Settle Dust |publisher=The Las Vegas Review-Journal |archivedate=12 May 2004}}</ref>
==Background== In 2003, and in response to the threat of federal funding loss due to unacceptable levels of dust pollution in the [[Las Vegas Valley]] (which then were in violation of US [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|Environmental Protection Agency]] policy), the "Dusty" character and its associated campaigns were created by Nevada-based agency Thomas Puckett<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thomaspuckett.com/portfolio/air-quality/ |title=Thomas Puckett: Clark County Department of Air Quality & Environmental Management |publisher=Thomas Puckett |date= |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> in conjunction with the [[Clark County, Nevada]] Department of Air Quality & Environmental Management.
Within three years the campaign succeeded<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.co.clark.nv.us/public_communications/news_releases/070103_air_quality.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070828023817/http://www.co.clark.nv.us/public_communications/news_releases/070103_air_quality.htm |title=County Air Quality Hits Major Milestone: Aggressive Dust Control Measures Successful in Keeping Air Clean |publisher=Clark County, Nevada (Official) |archivedate=3 January 2007}}</ref> in raising awareness of dust and its serious contribution to the Las Vegas Valley air pollution issue. $1.2-million in dust violation and other pollutant-related fines were channeled to the local school district during the period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Jan-04-Thu-2007/news/11774909.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070129050921/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2007/Jan-04-Thu-2007/news/11774909.html |title='Dusty the Dusthole' Successful: Clark County Meets Federal Air Quality Standard Three Years Straight |publisher=The Las Vegas Review-Journal |archivedate=4 January 2007}}</ref> <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Dusthole-watertruck-2.jpg|thumb|left|300px|Water truck silkscreen bearing Clark County Nevada "Dusty the Dusthole" mascot, 2004]] -->
Within a decade, the [[United States Environmental Protection Agency|EPA]] declared the Las Vegas Valley "clean," meeting US federal standards for airborne dust particles. The ''"Don't Be a Dusthole"'' campaign---by then retired---was cited as a positive contributing factor.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/news/water-environment/epa-says-dust-has-settled-las-vegas |title=EPA Says Dust Has Settled in Las Vegas |publisher=The Las Vegas Review-Journal |date=1 October 2014 |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref>
==Controversy== The "Dusty" character was so pervasive in the state of Nevada that [[off-roading]] groups defended themselves against the new awareness and scrutiny, having lost some of their longstanding travel privileges as result of Dusty's ubiquitous presence.<ref>[http://jeep.meetup.com/225/about/ About Jeep Thrills in Las Vegas - Jeep Thrills in Las Vegas (Las Vegas, NV) - Meetup.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
{{cquote|We need to provide a visible counterpoint to the image of "Dusty the Dusthole" which many people in the general public equate with off-roaders thanks to some very aggressive PR and billboard campaigns. The other side on this issue is spending a lot of money to demonize us and while we might not have the same deep pockets ourselves, we can get out there and raise public awareness in a more positive manner.}}
Conversely, the Las Vegas area media declared the Dusthole character "(not) such a bad guy after all",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://digitalcollections.mypubliclibrary.com/c/Henderson-Home-News/view/download/5489/?download=true&file=2007-01-11+-+Henderson+Home+Ne.pdf |title=Valley Lauded for Dust Control |publisher=Henderson Home News via MPL Digital Collections |date=17 January 2007 |accessdate=24 January 2016}}</ref> having saved the State of Nevada from a $280-million loss of funds thanks to the precipitous drop in dust and other pollutants from the time of the campaign's inception.
==Dusthole== The "Dusty the Dusthole" character was portrayed by lifelong Las Vegas resident Alan Burd. In the Dusthole ad campaign's opening years, Burd was a common sight at various fairs and functions as the Dusty character.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://viewnews.com/2004/VIEW-Jun-16-Wed-2004/East/24077053.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050115202900/http://viewnews.com/2004/VIEW-Jun-16-Wed-2004/East/24077053.html |title=Actor Nothing Like His Dusty Character |publisher=The Las Vegas Review-Journal: View |archivedate=16 June 2004}}</ref>
In December 2014, a bi-weekly [[Capitol Hill]]-based publication from [[National Association of Counties]] featured the Dusty character in a [[word search]] puzzle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naco.org/sites/default/files/documents/CNews_Dec15_2014.pdf |title=Vol. 46, No. 24 - Word Search (Page 6) |publisher=National Association of Counties |date=15 December 2014 |accessdate=25 January 2016}}</ref>

Mongolia's 1956 census counted [[Han Chinese|ethnic Chinese]] as 1.9% of the population; the United States government estimated their proportion to be 2% in 1987, or roughly 40,000 people.{{harvnb|LOC|1989|loc=[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+mn0052) Ch. 2.3.2]}} The 2000 census showed 1,323 permanent residents of Chinese descent; this figure does not include naturalised citizens, temporary residents, nor illegal immigrants.{{harvnb|Batbayar|2006|p=221}} [[Illegal immigrants]] from China were estimated at 10,000 in the 1990s; some use Mongolia as a transit point into [[Russia]].{{harvnb|Bedeski|1999|loc=Mongolia--A Demographic Buffer?}} ==Turkic Khaganate== Chinese artists were hired by [[Bilge Khagan]] of the [[Turkic Khaganate]].{{cite journal |last1=Ross|first1=E. Denison|last2=Thomsen|first2=Vilhelm |title=The Orkhon Inscriptions: Being a Translation of Professor Vilhelm Thomsen's Final Danish Rendering |journal=Bulletin of the School of Oriental Studies, University of London |date=1930 |volume=5 |issue=4 |pages=861–876 |jstor=607024}}{{cite journal|last=Scharlipp|first=Wolfgang-Eckhard|title=China and Tibet as Referred to in the Old Turkic Inscriptions}} Chinese text on a silk piece of yellow color was found in a Turkic tomb.{{cite report |author=Tsagaan Törbat |author2=Dunbüree Batsükh |author3=Jan Bemmann |author4=Thomas O. Höllmann |author5=Peter Zieme |title=A rock tomb of the ancient Turkic period in the Zhargalant Khairkhan Mountains, Khovd Aimag, with the oldest preserved horse-head fiddle in Mongolia – A preliminary report |url=https://www.vfgarch.uni-bonn.de/vfg/mitarbeiter/wissenschaftler-2/veroeffentlichungen/bemmann-horse-head-fiddle.pdf |publisher= |pages=369, 379–380 |docket= |access-date= }} ==Liao Dynasty== During the [[Liao dynasty]] Han Chinese lived in [[Bars-Hot|Kedun]], situated in present-day Mongolia.{{cite book|author=Michal Biran|title=The Empire of the Qara Khitai in Eurasian History: Between China and the Islamic World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B934LaVBaz8C&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=15 September 2005|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-84226-6|pages=27–}} Han farmers migrated in.{{cite web|url=http://www.wenshitiandi.com/html/81/3/3238/1.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-07-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807002024/http://www.wenshitiandi.com/html/81/3/3238/1.htm |archivedate=2016-08-07 |df= }} http://www.china10k.com/trad/history/5/51/51.htm {{cite web|url=http://www.guoxue123.com/new/0002/dfsdwm/022.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2016-07-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160910222615/http://www.guoxue123.com/new/0002/dfsdwm/022.htm |archivedate=2016-09-10 |df= }} http://blog.renren.com/share/229436183/9016553483 Chinese migrated to cities under Liao rule.{{cite book|author1=Denis C. Twitchett|author2=Herbert Franke|author3=John King Fairbank|title=The Cambridge History of China: Volume 6, Alien Regimes and Border States, 907-1368|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iN9Tdfdap5MC&pg=PA59#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=25 November 1994|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-24331-5|pages=59–}} ==Yuan dynasty== Han Chinese [[Semu#Similar practices in other areas of the Mongol Empire|officials and colonists]] were [[History of Siberia#Mongol conquest|sent by the Mongol Yuan dynasty]] to areas of [[Administrative divisions of the Yuan dynasty|Lingbei province]] ([[w:zh:和宁路|和宁路]] [[w:zh:益蘭州|益蘭州]] [[w:zh:謙州|謙州]]).[[History of Yuan]] 《 元史 》， The Yenisei area had a community of weavers of Chinese origin and Samarkand and Outer Mongolia both had artisans of Chinese origin seen by [[Qiu Chuji|Changchun]].{{cite book|author=Jacques Gernet|title=A History of Chinese Civilization|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jqb7L-pKCV8C&pg=PA377#v=onepage&q&f=false|date=31 May 1996|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-49781-7|pages=377–}} ==Ming dynasty== The Liaodong Han Chinese military frontiersmen were prone to mixing and acculturating with (non-Han) tribesmen.{{cite book|author=Frederic E. Wakeman|title=The Great Enterprise: The Manchu Reconstruction of Imperial Order in Seventeenth-century China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8nXLwSG2O8AC&pg=PA39#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=1985|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-04804-1|pages=39–}} Han Chinese soldiers served in the Yuan army against the Ming, and the Mongols were joined by many Chinese defectors. The Mongol Mangui served in the Ming military and fought the Manchus, dying in battle against a Manchu raid. Some Chinese who lived among the Mongols of Inner Mongolians, while in their youth, adopted Mongol culture and married a Mongol women but when he became old he would come back and lived with the Han Chinese again. One Han Chinese military officer who defected to the Mongols was "Monkey Li" (Li Huai) who fought against the Ming.{{cite book|author=Frederic E. Wakeman|title=The Great Enterprise: The Manchu Reconstruction of Imperial Order in Seventeenth-century China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8nXLwSG2O8AC&pg=PA41#v=onepage&q&f=false|year=1985|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-04804-1|pages=41–}}{{cite book|author=Frederic E. Wakeman|title=The Great Enterprise: The Manchu Reconstruction of Imperial Order in Seventeenth-century China|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8nXLwSG2O8AC&pg=PA41&dq=li+huai+monkey+li&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAGoVChMI2vC8r7b_yAIVhlw-Ch03XAgO#v=onepage&q=li%20huai%20monkey%20li&f=false|year=1985|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-04804-1|pages=41–}}{{cite book|title=Oriens extremus|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vFjVAAAAMAAJ&q=li+huai+monkey+li&dq=li+huai+monkey+li&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CE0Q6AEwCWoVChMI2vC8r7b_yAIVhlw-Ch03XAgO|year=1959|publisher=Kommissionverlag O. Harrasowitz.|page=137}} ==Qing Dynasty== Historically, the [[Gobi Desert|Gobi]] served as a barrier to large-scale Chinese settlement in what was, before 1921, called [[Outer Mongolia]]; the unsuitability of most of the territory for [[agriculture in Mongolia|agriculture]] made settlement less attractive. Some Chinese settlements in Mongolia were founded in 1725, when farmers moved there by decree of the [[Qing Dynasty]] to grow food for soldiers fighting the [[Dzungars]]. They were established in the [[Orkhon River|Orkhon]] and [[Tuul River|Tuul]] river basins, and in 1762, in the [[Khovd (city)|Khovd]] region. After the fighting ended, the Qing closed off Mongolia to immigration{{harvnb|Batbayar|2006|p=216}} and occasionally evicted Chinese merchants. Despite those restrictions, Chinese trade firms continually penetrated the country, concentrating mainly in [[Ulaanbaatar|Ikh Khüree]], [[Uliastai]], [[Khovd (city)|Khovd]] and [[Kyakhta]]. Their trade practices and the lifestyle of the Mongolian nobility lead to an ever-increasing indebtedness of the banners, nobles, and ordinary people, and Chinese businesses became a target of public discontent as early as [[Chingünjav]]'s uprising in 1756. The spill-over from the [[Dungan revolt (1862–1877)|Dungan rebellions]] of the 1870s into Mongolia also saw a number of Chinese businesses in Khovd and Uliastai destroyed. Many of the Chinese merchants lived in Mongolia only seasonally or until they had made enough money to return to China. Others took Mongolian wives, at least for the time of being in Mongolia. In 1906, the [[Qing Dynasty]] began to implement policies aimed at a Han-Chinese colonization of Outer Mongolia along the lines of those in Inner Mongolia, but these policies never took full effect because the Dynasty collapsed and Mongolia declared independence in 1911. The total Han Chinese population at that time, mainly consisting of traders and artisans, but also of some colonists, can be estimated to have been at some ten thousand.{{fact|date=May 2017}} ==Since 1911== [[File:First Day Russian Post in Mongolia Urga 1915.jpg|thumb| A 1915 cover, red band from [[Ulaanbaatar|Urga]] to [[Beijing]], written by Chinese merchant.]] Upon [[Mongolia]]'s declaration of independence, many Chinese became victims of atrocities,{{Citation needed|date=December 2007}} particularly in [[Khovd (city)|Khovd]]. However, after 1912, Chinese businesses were able to continue their operations, including collection of debts, largely unimpeded. It was only the establishment of communism that meant an end to Chinese trade in Mongolia. Ever-increasing obstacles to commerce were created, and the closure of the border to China for imports in 1928 meant an end for Chinese enterprise in the country. With the [[People's Republic of China]] development aid projects of the 1950s, many Han Chinese entered Mongolia, beginning in 1955. By 1961, they had reached a number of 20,000. However, after the [[Sino-Soviet split]] in the early 1960s, in which Mongolia sided with the Soviets, China eventually withdrew most of its workers.{{cite web|url=http://www.wilsoncenter.org/sites/default/files/ACF4CA.pdf|author=Sergey Radchenko|title=The Soviets' Best Friend in Asia|page=14}} At the same time, Mongolian politicians or academicians with alleged links to China (e.g. Ts. Lookhuuz or G. Sükhbaatar) became victims of political purges. In the early 1980s, Ulan Bator was reported to have a small Chinese community, which published a Chinese-language newspaper and which looked to the Chinese embassy there for moral support. However, in 1983, Mongolia systematically began expelling some of the remaining 7,000 Chinese contract workers in Mongolia to China. At the same time, ethnic Chinese who had become naturalized citizens were reported to be unaffected. Because the presence and the status of Chinese residents in Mongolia were politically sensitive subjects, Mongolian sources usually avoided mentioning the Chinese at all. After the introduction of [[democracy]], another wave of Chinese immigrants has entered the country. Many of the migrants work in the construction sector, while others run small or medium enterprises. Negative sentiment against Chinese migrants remains;{{Cite book|url=https://www.amazon.com/Sinophobia-Anxiety-Violence-Mongolian-Identity/dp/082483982X|title=Sinophobia: Anxiety, Violence, and the Making of Mongolian Identity|last=Bille|first=Franck|date=2014-12-30|publisher=Univ of Hawaii Pr|isbn=9780824839826|language=English}} China is seen as a potential threat to Mongolia's security and cultural identity.{{citation|url=http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m0WDP/is_2005_April_11/ai_n13601320|title=Anti-Chinese sentiment swelling in Mongolia|date=2005-04-11|accessdate=2007-02-23|periodical=Asian Economic News}} However, not all recent immigrants from China are ethnic [[Han Chinese]]; in particular, there is a number of [[ethnic Mongols in China|Inner Mongolians]].{{harvnb|Uradyn|1998|p=188}} ==See also== *[[Demographics of Mongolia]] *[[Koreans in Mongolia]] ==References== ===Notes=== {{loc}} {{reflist|2}} ===Sources=== *{{citation|first=Robert A.|last=Rupen|title=The Fiftieth Anniversary of the Mongolian People's Republic: 1921-1971|journal=Asian Survey|volume=13|date=May 1973|doi=10.1525/as.1973.13.5.01p0332s|pages=458|issue=5}} *{{citation|publisher=United States Library of Congress|date=June 1989|accessdate=2007-02-28|series=Country Studies|title=Mongolia|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/mntoc.html|ref=CITEREFLOC1989}} *{{citation|last=Uradyn|first=Erden Bulag|year=1998|chapter=Inner Mongols as 'Other' to Mongols|pages=171–214|title=Nationalism and hybridity in Mongolia|series=Oxford studies in social and cultural anthropology|isbn=978-0-19-823357-2}} *{{citation|last=Bedeski|first=Robert|title=The Chinese Diaspora, Mongolia and the Sino-Russian Frontier|date=November 1999|series=JPRI Working Papers|volume=62|url=http://www.jpri.org/publications/workingpapers/wp62.html|accessdate=2007-02-23}} *{{citation|chapter=Foreign migration issues in Mongolia|last=Batbayar|first=Tsedendamba|editor-last=Akaha|editor-first=Tsuneo| title=Crossing National Borders: Human Migration Issues in Northeast Asia|publisher=United Nations University Press|isbn=92-808-1117-7|year=2006|pages=215–235}} {{Overseas Chinese}} [[Category:Mongolian people of Chinese descent| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Mongolia|Chinese]] [[Category:Chinese diaspora by country|Mongolia]] [[Category:Chinese diaspora in Asia]] [[Category:China–Mongolia relations]]

– looking back == Ever since the emergence of [[Early Modern Switzerland|Switzerland]] and [[Early Modern Germany|Germany]] as distinct nations in the [[Early Modern period]] – the Swiss became exempt from the jurisdiction of the [[Imperial Diet (Holy Roman Empire)|Imperial Diet]] in 1499 as a result of the [[Swabian War]], formal recognition of Swiss independence dates to 1648 ([[Peace of Westphalia]]) – there has been considerable population movement in both directions, but meaningful population statistics become available only after the [[Napoleonic era]], with the formation of the [[restored Swiss Confederacy]] and the [[German Confederation]] in 1815. A number of Germans, and of people living in Germany, fled the [[militarism]] of [[German Empire]] and, shortly afterwards, the [[Nazism|Nazi regime]] or were expelled by it, in the first decades of the 20th century and sought refuge in Switzerland, among other places. ==21st century - 1st decades== ===Demographics=== Because of the unequal size of the two countries, Germany being roughly ten times larger than Switzerland, German residents in Switzerland have a much greater visibility than Swiss residents in Germany: In 2007, about 37,000 Swiss nationals, or about 1 in 180 Swiss citizens, lived in Germany, accounting for just 0.05% of German population. At the same time, about 224,000 German nationals, or 1 in 350 German citizens, lived in Switzerland, accounting for 3% of Swiss population.Note that this comparison ignores [[dual citizenship]]. As of 2007, Switzerland recorded 75,000 Swiss citizens residing in Germany, while Germany recorded only 37,000 foreign nationals with Swiss citizenship, suggesting that the remaining 38,000 people have dual Swiss-German citizenship.{{Dubious|date=June 2011}} The number of Germans in Switzerland has doubled in the period of 2002 to 2009. The reason for this is the [[Switzerland – European Union relations|Swiss–European treaty]] regarding the [[freedom of movement for workers]], activated in 2002.{{fact|date=January 2018}} While the freedom of movement treaty applies to all EU citizens, German nationals have been the main beneficiaries because their proficiency in the [[Standard German|German language]] allows them to take qualified jobs in [[German-speaking Switzerland]] without the added difficulty of a language barrier.{{fact|date=January 2018}} As of 2009, they were the second-largest expatriate group in Switzerland, numbering 266,000 (or 3.4% of total Swiss population) second to the [[Italian immigration to Switzerland|Italians]] with 294,000 (3.7% of total Swiss population). 22,000 were born in Switzerland (of these, 18,000 were minors, children born to German parents living in Switzerland). 19,000 Germans with permanent residence in Switzerland were married to a Swiss citizen. In 2007, the number of Germans in Switzerland passed the historical maximum of 220,000 Germans recorded prior to [[World War I]]. However, because of the lower total population at the time, the pre-1914 fraction of Germans relative to total Swiss population was as high as 6%. The rate of [[Swiss nationality law|naturalizations]] has also steeply increased since 2007.''[http://www.tagesanzeiger.ch/schweiz/standard/Pro-Tag-werden-10-Deutsche-eingebuergert/story/27541536?track Pro Tag werden 10 Deutsche eingebürgert]'', [[Tages-Anzeiger]], 30 May 2010. The reason for this, beyond the rising number of qualifying German nationals who had resided in Switzerland for the twelve years required by Swiss nationality law, was a change in German nationality law which permitted German nationals to hold Swiss-German [[dual citizenship]] (while prior to 2007, Germans wishing to be naturalized in Switzerland had to give up their German citizenship).Renat Künzi: ''[http://www.swissinfo.ch/ger/Home/Archiv/Deutsch-schweizerische_Doppelbuerger_behalten_roten_Pass.html?cid=6083040 Deutsch-schweizerische Doppelbürger behalten roten Pass]'', [[Swissinfo]], 31 August 2007 Historical demographics 1995–2014: {|class="wikitable" |- align=right | | year || 1995 || 1996 || 1997 || 1998 || 1999 || 2000 || 2001 || 2002 || 2003 || 2004 || 2005 || 2006 || 2007 || 2008 || '''2009''' || 2010 || 2011 || 2012 || 2013 || 2014 |- align=right | | German population

Already at the historical maximum of German presence in Switzerland in 1910, German population in Zürich was as high as 41,000 or 22% of the city's total population. As of 2009, German population in Zürich was at about 30,000, or close to 8%. Helbling concludes – summing up further literature and media – that "German immigrants put in danger Swiss characteristics as much as immigrants from the Balkans", that "contrary to many other studies, education does not improve attitudes towards Germans", that "people who are young and seek to improve their job position are significantly more Germanophobic than those who are satisfied with their current job situation and are already established" and that "it appears that as much as low-skilled workers fear that poorly educated immigrants take their jobs, well-educated Swiss consider German immigrants as competitors on the job market". As to the feeling of the "intimidated" part of Swiss-Germans, feeling being left-behind, the journalist Gunhild Kübler, a German living in Switzerland, remarks: {{Quote|China has 1.3 billion people, 16 times more than Germany. The Federal Republic again exactly 16 times as many as the German-speaking Switzerland. So, if a German would put himself in the position of an intimidated German Swiss, he may well imagine that his country is not adjacent in the East to the Czech Republic but to China.|Gunhild KüblerMarco Lauer: ''[http://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/international/integration-i-ha-di-gaern-deutsche-in-der-schweiz/1543294.html Integration: I ha di gärn! - Deutsche in der Schweiz]'', [[Tagesspiegel]] June 24, 2009 / also as: ''[http://www.taz.de/!5153955/ Integration für Deutsche in der Schweiz: "Grüezi Gummihälse!"]'', [[Die Tageszeitung|TAZ]], October 21, 2009}} Cristiana Baldauf, one of the course leaders of the Swiss integration courses for Germans and Austrians, and a German and Swiss citizen, with a German mother and Italian father, says: {{Quote|I think, that what the Swiss dislike about the Germans, is the German in themselves.|Cristiana Baldauf}} ;Integration – differences in culture, behavior, manners, language problems Experience shows that the excitement fades away on every major wave of immigration with its increasing integration. So, a.o. also Helbling cites the popular example of now largely integrated Italians, who came in one of the "waves" in the '60s as [[gastarbeiter]]s to Switzerland, and whose generations are today a part of the society of the German-speaking Switzerland, without giving up their culture. {{Quote|It is particularly notable that Italians are the most liked immigrants, while at their arrival in the 1950s and 1960s they were the group of immigrants that attracted the most hostilities.|Marc HelblingMarc Helbling summing up Gianni D’Amato (2001) and Josef M. Niederberger (2004) in: ''[https://bibliothek.wzb.eu/pdf/2010/iv10-702.pdf Germanophobia in Switzerland]'' (PDF), Discussion Paper SP IV 2010-702, [[WZB]] Berlin, May 2010, p.6}} In the relations of the German-Swiss and the incoming German come up, overtly or covertly, specific misunderstandings – perceived similarities, different mentalities and manners and, now already well known, language problems and differences.Cristiana Baldauf-Hornig: ''[http://www.sueddeutsche.de/politik/deutsche-in-der-schweiz-vorsicht-vor-fraenkli-und-grueezi-1.79758 Deutsche in der Schweiz: Vorsicht vor Fränkli und Grüezi] – Wie es Deutsche schaffen, bei Schweizern nicht anzuecken'', [[Süddeutsche Zeitung|SZ]], 17 May 2010see also ''Literatur - Beletristik, populär'' on German Wikipedia Cristiana Baldauf comments on the fundamental differences, on the petty ones and on the different languages: {{Quote|One has to bear in mind that the Swiss are ticking quite differently as we do.|Cristiana Baldauf}} {{Quote|Often just minor differences bear a potential for misunderstanding. | Cristiana Baldauf}} {{Quote|The language plays a central role in the misunderstanding. The modern '''history of hypertension''' begins with the understanding of the cardiovascular system based on the work of physician [[William Harvey]] (1578–1657), who described the circulation of blood in his book "''De motu cordis''". The English clergyman [[Stephen Hales]] made the first published measurement of blood pressure in 1733.<ref name=Esunge1991rev/><ref name=Kotchen2011>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kotchen TA | title = Historical trends and milestones in hypertension research: a model of the process of translational research | journal = Hypertension | volume = 58 | issue = 4 | pages = 522–38 | date = October 2011 | pmid = 21859967 | doi = 10.1161/HYPERTENSIONAHA.111.177766 }}</ref> Descriptions of what would come to be called hypertension came from among others, [[Thomas Young (scientist)|Thomas Young]] in 1808 and especially [[Richard Bright (physician)|Richard Bright]] in 1836.<ref name=Esunge1991rev/> Bright noted a link between cardiac hypertrophy and kidney disease, and subsequently kidney disease was often termed [[Bright's disease]] in this period. In 1850 George Johnson suggested that the thickened blood vessels seen in the kidney in Bright's disease might be an adaptation to elevated blood pressure.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Johnson G | title = On the proximate cause of albuminous urine and dropsy, and on the pathology of the renal blood-vessels in Bright's Disease | journal = Medico-Chirurgical Transactions | volume = 33 | pages = 107–20 | date = 1850 | pmid = 20895925 | pmc = 2104234 }}</ref> William Senhouse Kirkes in 1855 and Ludwig Traube in 1856 also proposed, based on pathological observations, that elevated pressure could account for the association between left ventricular hypertrophy to kidney damage in Bright's disease.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cameron JS, Hicks J | title = High blood pressure and the kidney: the forgotten contribution of William Senhouse Kirkes | journal = Kidney International | volume = 57 | issue = 2 | pages = 724–34 | date = February 2000 | pmid = 10652052 | doi = 10.1046/j.1523-1755.2000.00895.x }}</ref> Samuel Wilks observed that left ventricular hypertrophy and diseased arteries were not necessarily associated with diseased kidneys,<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cameron JS, Hicks J | title = Frederick Akbar Mahomed and his role in the description of hypertension at Guy's Hospital | journal = Kidney International | volume = 49 | issue = 5 | pages = 1488–506 | date = May 1996 | pmid = 8731118 | doi = 10.1038/ki.1996.209 }}</ref> implying that high blood pressure might occur in people with healthy kidneys; however the first report of elevated blood pressure in a person without evidence of kidney disease was made by [[Frederick Akbar Mahomed]] in 1874 using a [[sphygmograph]].<ref>{{cite book |editor=Swales JD|title=Manual of hypertension|publisher=Blackwell Science |location=Oxford |year=1995 |pages=xiii |isbn=0-86542-861-1}}</ref> The concept of hypertensive disease as a generalized circulatory disease was taken up by [[Clifford Allbutt|Sir Clifford Allbutt]], who termed the condition "hyperpiesia".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/hyperpiesiahyper00shaw|title=Hyperpiesia and hyperpiesis (hypertension) : a clinical, pathological & experimental study|last=Shaw|first=H. Batty | name-list-format = vanc |date=1922|publisher=London : Frowde and Hodder & Stoughton|others=University of California Libraries}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/30894228|title=Hypertension : pathophysiology, diagnosis, and management|last=Freis|first=Edward|publisher=Raven Press|others=|year=1995|isbn=9780781701570|editor-last=Laragh|editor-first=John | name-list-format = vanc |edition=2nd|location=New York|pages=2742|chapter=Historical Development of Antihypertensive Treatment|oclc=30894228|editor-last2=Brenner|editor-first2=Barry}}</ref> However hypertension as a medical entity really came into being in 1896 with the invention of the cuff-based [[sphygmomanometer]] by [[Scipione Riva-Rocci]] in 1896,<ref>{{cite book | title=A century of arterial hypertension 1896–1996 | editor=Postel-Vinay N |page=213 | location=Chichester | publisher=Wiley | year=1996 | isbn=0-471-96788-2}}</ref> which allowed [[blood pressure]] to be measured in the clinic. In 1905, [[Nikolai Korotkoff]] improved the technique by describing the [[Korotkoff sounds]] that are heard when the artery is ausculated with a stethoscope while the sphygmomanometer cuff is deflated.<ref name=Kotchen2011/>
The term [[essential hypertension]] ('Essentielle Hypertonie') was coined by Eberhard Frank in 1911 to describe elevated blood pressure for which no cause could be found.<ref name="Korner2007">{{cite book|author=Paul I. Korner Professor of Medicine Monash University (Emeritus) and Director of the|title=Essential Hypertension and Its Causes : Neural and Non-Neural Mechanisms: Neural and Non-Neural Mechanisms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q-HIVbL4OxAC&pg=PA4|date=11 May 2007|publisher=Oxford University Press, USA|isbn=978-0-19-535740-0|pages=4–}}</ref> In 1928, the term [[malignant hypertension]] was coined by physicians from the [[Mayo Clinic]] to describe a syndrome of very high blood pressure, severe retinopathy and inadequate kidney function which usually resulted in death within a year from [[stroke]]s, [[heart failure]] or [[kidney failure]].<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Keith NM, Wagener HP, Kernohan JW | title=The syndrome of malignant hypertension | journal=Arch. Intern. Med. | year=1928 | volume=41 | pages=141–188 |doi=10.1001/archinte.1928.00130140003001 | issue=2}}</ref> A prominent individual with severe hypertension was [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Bruenn HG | title = Clinical notes on the illness and death of President Franklin D. Roosevelt | journal = Annals of Internal Medicine | volume = 72 | issue = 4 | pages = 579–91 | date = April 1970 | pmid = 4908628 | doi = 10.7326/0003-4819-72-4-579 }}</ref> However, while the menace of severe or malignant hypertension was well recognised, the risks of more moderate elevations of blood pressure were uncertain and the benefits of treatment doubtful. Consequently, hypertension was often classified into "malignant" and "benign". In 1931, John Hay, Professor of Medicine at [[Liverpool University]], wrote that "there is some truth in the saying that the greatest danger to a man with a high blood pressure lies in its discovery, because then some fool is certain to try and reduce it".<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Hay J | title = A British Medical Association Lecture on THE SIGNIFICANCE OF A RAISED BLOOD PRESSURE | journal = British Medical Journal | volume = 2 | issue = 3679 | pages = 43–7 | date = July 1931 | pmid = 20776269 | pmc = 2314188 | doi = 10.1136/bmj.2.3679.43 }}</ref><ref name=Moser/> This view was echoed by the eminent US cardiologist [[Paul Dudley White]] in 1937, who suggested that "hypertension may be an important compensatory mechanism which should not be tampered with, even if we were certain that we could control it".<ref>{{cite book | author=White PD |title=Heart Disease | edition=2nd | location=New York, NY | publisher=MacMillan Co. | year=1937| page=326}}</ref> Charles Friedberg's 1949 classic textbook "Diseases of the Heart",<ref>{{cite book | author=Friedberg CK | title=Diseases of the Heart| location=Philadelphia, PA| publisher=WB Saunders Co | year=1949}}</ref> stated that "people with 'mild benign' hypertension ... [defined as blood pressures up to levels of 210/100 mm Hg] ... need not be treated".<ref name=Moser>{{cite journal | vauthors = Moser M | title = Historical perspectives on the management of hypertension | journal = Journal of Clinical Hypertension | volume = 8 | issue = 8 Suppl 2 | pages = 15–20; quiz 39 | date = August 2006 | pmid = 16894244 | doi = 10.1111/j.1524-6175.2006.05836.x }}</ref> However the tide of medical opinion was turning: it was increasingly recognised in the 1950s that "benign" hypertension was not harmless.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Pickering GW | title = The natural history of hypertension | journal = British Medical Bulletin | volume = 8 | issue = 4 | pages = 305–9 | year = 1952 | pmid = 12987687 }}</ref> Over the next decade increasing evidence accumulated from actuarial reports<ref name=Kotchen2011/><ref>{{cite book | author=Society of Actuaries Committee on Mortality |title=Build and blood pressure study, 1959| publisher=Society of Actuaries | location=Chicago, IL | year=1960}}</ref> and longitudinal studies, such as the [[Framingham Heart Study]],<ref>{{cite book | chapter=Section 30: Some characteristics related to the incidence of cardiovascular disease and death: 18 year follow-up | title=The Framingham Study; DHEW Publication No. (NIH) 74-599 | publisher=National Heart and Lung Institute| location=Bethesda, MD| year=1974}}</ref> that "benign" hypertension increased death and cardiovascular disease, and that these risks increased in a graded manner with increasing blood pressure across the whole spectrum of population blood pressures. Subsequently, the [[National Institutes of Health]] also sponsored other population studies, which additionally showed that African Americans had a higher burden of hypertension and its complications.<ref name=Dustan>{{cite journal | vauthors = Dustan HP, Roccella EJ, Garrison HH | title = Controlling hypertension. A research success story | journal = Archives of Internal Medicine | volume = 156 | issue = 17 | pages = 1926–35 | date = September 1996 | pmid = 8823146 | doi = 10.1001/archinte.156.17.1926 }}</ref>
==Treatment and Medications== Historically the treatment for what was called the "hard pulse disease" consisted in reducing the quantity of blood by [[blood letting]] or the application of [[leech]]es.<ref name="Esunge1991rev">{{cite journal | vauthors = Esunge PM | title = From blood pressure to hypertension: the history of research | journal = Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine | volume = 84 | issue = 10 | pages = 621 | date = October 1991 | pmid = 1744849 | pmc = 1295564 }}</ref> This was advocated by The [[Yellow Emperor]] of China, [[Aulus Cornelius Celsus|Cornelius Celsus]], [[Galen]], and [[Hippocrates]].<ref name="Esunge1991rev" />
In the late 19th and early to mid 20th centuries, many therapies were used to treat hypertension,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ayman|first=David| name-list-format = vanc |date=1930-07-26|title=An evaluation of therapeutic results in essential hypertension: i. the interpretation of symptomatic relief |journal=Journal of the American Medical Association |volume=95 |issue=4 |pages=246–249 |doi=10.1001/jama.1930.02720040004002 }}</ref><ref name="Evans 199–228">{{cite journal | vauthors = Evans W, Loughnan O | title = The drug treatment of hyperpiesia | journal = British Heart Journal | volume = 1 | issue = 3 | pages = 199–228 | date = July 1939 | pmid = 18609819 | pmc = 503854 | doi = 10.1136/hrt.1.3.199 }}</ref> but few were effective<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Ayman|first=David | name-list-format = vanc |date=1931-06-20 |title=An evaluation of therapeutic results in essential hypertension: II. the interpretation of blood pressure reductions|journal=Journal of the American Medical Association|volume=96|issue=25|pages=2091–2094|doi=10.1001/jama.1931.02720510011003 }}</ref><ref name="Evans 199–228"/> and these were poorly tolerated.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ayman|first=David | name-list-format = vanc |date=1931-05-30|title=Potassium thiocyanate in the treatment of essential hypertension: its impracticability |journal=Journal of the American Medical Association |volume=96 |issue=22 |pages=1852–1857 |doi=10.1001/jama.1931.02720480010004 }}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite journal | vauthors = Moser M | title = Historical perspectives on the management of hypertension | journal = Journal of Clinical Hypertension | volume = 8 | issue = 8 Suppl 2 | pages = 15–20; quiz 39 | date = August 2006 | pmid = 16894244 | doi = 10.1111/j.1524-6175.2006.05836.x }}</ref> Therapies used in that period included strict sodium restriction (for example the [[rice diet]]<ref name="Esunge1991rev" />),<ref name=":2">{{Cite book | first1 = John H | last1 = Laragh | first2 = Barry M | last2 = Brenner | name-list-format = vanc | url = https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/30894228 |title=Hypertension : pathophysiology, diagnosis, and management |date=1995 |publisher=Raven Press|isbn=9780781701570|edition=2nd|location=New York|oclc=30894228}}</ref> [[sympathectomy]] (surgical ablation of parts of the [[sympathetic nervous system]]),<ref name=":2" /> and pyrogen therapy (injection of substances that caused a fever, indirectly reducing blood pressure).<ref name="Esunge1991rev" /><ref name="Dustan" /> The first chemical for hypertension, [[sodium thiocyanate]], was used in 1900 but had many side effects<ref name=":1" /> and was unpopular.<ref name="Esunge1991rev" /> Other treatments, such as [[barbiturate]]s, [[bismuth]], and [[bromide]]s were mainly supportive rather than therapeutic.<ref name=":0" /> Other drugs were used after the [[World War II|Second World War]], the most popular and reasonably effective of which were [[tetramethylammonium chloride]] and its derivative [[hexamethonium]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wien R, Mason DF | title = Some actions of hexamethonium and certain homologues | journal = British Journal of Pharmacology and Chemotherapy | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = 611–29 | date = December 1951 | pmid = 14904886 | pmc = 1509152 | doi = 10.1111/j.1476-5381.1951.tb00672.x }}</ref> Also used in the post-war period were [[hydralazine]]<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Johnson RP | title = The treatment of hypertension with 1-hydrazinophthalazine (apresoline) | journal = American Heart Journal | volume = 46 | issue = 4 | pages = 592–601 | date = October 1953 | pmid = 13092045 | doi = 10.1016/0002-8703(53)90069-6 }}</ref> and [[reserpine]] (derived from the medicinal plant ''[[Rauwolfia serpentina]]'').<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Vakil RJ | title = Rauwolfia serpentina in the treatment of high blood pressure; a review of the literature | journal = Circulation | volume = 12 | issue = 2 | pages = 220–9 | date = August 1955 | pmid = 13240803 | doi = 10.1161/01.cir.12.2.220 }}</ref>
A major breakthrough was achieved in the 1950s with the discovery of well-tolerated oral [[diuretics]], the first of which was [[chlorothiazide]] (Diuril).<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Greene JA | title = Releasing the flood waters: diuril and the reshaping of hypertension | journal = Bulletin of the History of Medicine | volume = 79 | issue = 4 | pages = 749–94 | date = 2005 | pmid = 16327086 | doi = 10.1353/bhm.2005.0153 }}</ref> This was derived from the antibiotic [[sulfanilamide]] and became available in 1958.<ref name="Esunge1991rev" /><ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Novello FC, Sprague JM | title=Benzothiadiazine dioxides as novel diuretics | journal=J. Am. Chem. Soc. | year=1957 | volume=79 | pages=2028–2029 |doi=10.1021/ja01565a079|issue=8}}</ref> A [[randomized controlled trial]] sponsored by the [[United States Department of Veterans Affairs|Veterans Administration]] comparing [[hydrochlorothiazide]] plus reserpine plus hydralazine versus placebo had to be stopped early because those not receiving treatment developed many more complications and it was deemed unethical to withhold treatment from them. The study continued in people with lower blood pressures and showed that treatment even in people with mild hypertension more than halved the risk of cardiovascular death.<ref name=Moser/><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Freis ED | title = The Veterans Administration cooperative study on antihypertensive agents. Implications for stroke prevention | journal = Stroke | volume = 5 | issue = 1 | pages = 76–7 | year = 1974 | pmid = 4811316 | doi = 10.1161/01.STR.5.1.76 }}</ref> In 1975, the [[Lasker Award|Lasker Special Public Health Award]] was awarded to the team that developed chlorothiazide.<ref name=Dustan/> The results of these studies prompted public health campaigns to increase public awareness of hypertension and promoted the measurement and treatment of high blood pressure. These measures appear to have contributed at least in part to the observed 50% fall in stroke and ischemic heart disease between 1972 and 1994.<ref name=Dustan/>
Soon more drugs became available to treat hypertension. The British physician [[James W. Black]] developed [[beta blocker]]s in the early 1960s;<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Black JW, Crowther AF, Shanks RG, Smith LH, Dornhorst AC | title = A new adrenergic betareceptor antagonist | journal = Lancet | volume = 1 | issue = 7342 | pages = 1080–1 | date = May 1964 | pmid = 14132613 | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(64)91275-9 }}</ref> these were initially used for [[angina pectoris|angina]], but turned out to lower blood pressure. Black received the 1976 [[Lasker-DeBakey Clinical Medical Research Award|Lasker Award]] and in 1988 the [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] for his discovery.<ref name=Dustan/> The next class of antihypertensives to be discovered were [[calcium channel blockers]]. The first member was [[verapamil]], a derivative of [[papaverine]] that was initially thought to be a beta blocker and used for angina, but then turned out to have a different mode of action and was shown to lower blood pressure.<ref name=Dustan/> The [[renin–angiotensin system]] was known to play an important role in blood pressure regulation, and [[angiotensin converting enzyme]] (ACE) inhibitors were developed through [[Drug design|rational drug design]]. In 1977 [[captopril]], an orally active agent, was described;<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Ondetti MA, Rubin B, Cushman DW | title = Design of specific inhibitors of angiotensin-converting enzyme: new class of orally active antihypertensive agents | journal = Science | volume = 196 | issue = 4288 | pages = 441–4 | date = April 1977 | pmid = 191908 | doi = 10.1126/science.191908 }}</ref> this led to the development of a number of other ACE inhibitors.<ref name=Dustan/> More recently [[angiotensin receptor blockers]] and [[renin inhibitors]] have also been introduced as antihypertensive agents.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Wexler RR, Greenlee WJ, Irvin JD, Goldberg MR, Prendergast K, Smith RD, Timmermans PB | title = Nonpeptide angiotensin II receptor antagonists: the next generation in antihypertensive therapy | journal = Journal of Medicinal Chemistry | volume = 39 | issue = 3 | pages = 625–56 | date = February 1996 | pmid = 8576904 | doi = 10.1021/jm9504722 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Jensen C, Herold P, Brunner HR | title = Aliskiren: the first renin inhibitor for clinical treatment | journal = Nature Reviews. Drug Discovery | volume = 7 | issue = 5 | pages = 399–410 | date = May 2008 | pmid = 18340340 | doi = 10.1038/nrd2550 }}</ref>

{{Infobox language |name = Irarutu |altname = Irahutu |nativename = Kasira |states = [[Indonesia]] |region = [[Bomberai Peninsula]] |speakers = {{formatnum:4000}} |date=1987 |ref = e18 |familycolor = Austronesian |fam2 = [[Malayo-Polynesian languages|Malayo-Polynesian]] (MP) |fam3 = [[Nuclear Malayo-Polynesian languages|Nuclear MP]] |fam4 = ([[Central–Eastern Malayo-Polynesian languages|Central–Eastern]]) |fam5 = [[Halmahera–Cenderawasih languages|Halmahera–Cenderawasih]] |fam6 = Irarutu–Nabi |iso3 = irh |glotto=irar1238 |glottorefname=Irarutu }}
'''Irarutu''', '''Irahutu''', or '''Kasira''', is an [[Austronesian language]] of most of the interior of the [[Bomberai Peninsula]] of New Guinea.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Trends in Linguistics: Comparative Austronesian Dictionary An Introduction to Austronesian Studies Part 1|last=Tyron|first=Darrell|publisher=|year=1995|isbn=3111797082|location=|pages=638|via=}}</ref> The name “Irarutu” comes from the language itself, where “ira” conjoins with “ru” to create “their voice”. When put together with “tu”, which on its own means “true”, the meaning of the name becomes “Their true voice” or “The people’s true language”.<ref name=":1" />
[[Kuri language (Austronesian)|Kuri]] is very close lexically, but has not been formally classified. Other than this, Irarutu is quite divergent among the [[Central Malayo-Polynesian languages]]. Irarutu is one of the many languages found in the South Halmahera subgroup of Austronesian languages.<ref name=":0" /> There are seven variations found within the language: Nabi, Babo, Kasuri, Fruata, South-Arguni, East-Arguni, North-Arguni.<ref name=":0" />
== Grammar == Irarutu follows the "Subject, Verb, Object" (SVO) format in word order. Adjectives such as "big" or a numbered value come after the noun, but for lineage-related matters the initial ancestor comes before the descendant.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />
=== Consonants<ref name=":0" /> ===
{| class="wikitable" ! !Bilabial !Dental/Alvelar !Palatal !Velar !Laryngeal |- !Stops |p b |t d |c ɟ |k g | |- !Fricatives |f |s | | |h |- !Nasals |m |n | | | |- !Flaps | |r | | | |- !Semivowels |w |y | | | |} /p, t, c, k, b, d, ɟ, g, are all stops with /p, t, c, k/ being voiceless and /b, d, ɟ, g,/ being voiced. All stop consonants can be placed in any position (beginning, middle, or end) with the exception of /c/ which cannot be placed in the ending position.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=A Grammar of Irarutu, A language of West Papua, Indonesia, With Historical Analysis|last=Jackson|first=Jason Alexander Johann|publisher=University of Hawaii at Manoa|year=2014|isbn=|location=University of Hawaii at Manoa|pages=7, 43, 44, 52|via=}}</ref>
/f, s, h/ are all voiceless fricatives. /f/ is found in all 3 positions and is sometimes pronounced as a voiced /v/ due to biological features of Native Irarutu speakers. /s/ is also found in all 3 positions but is never voiced. /h/ is a new consonant sound which may have come from Arabic or a nearby dialect. /h/ is only found in initial and middle positions.<ref name=":1" />
/m, n/ are both voiced nasals. Both consonants are found in all 3 positions.<ref name=":1" />
/r/ is found in most Irarutu dialects, but is sometimes switched out with /l/.<ref name=":1" />
=== Vowels<ref name=":0" /> ===
{| class="wikitable" ! !Front !Central !Back |- !High |i ɪ |y |u |- !Mid |e | |o |- !Low | |a | |} 7 types of vowels are found in Irarutu, /a, e, ɪ, i, o, u, y/. The vowels can then be formed in two different ways, one being monophthongs and the other being diphthongs. Monophthongs are a single sounding vowel while diphthongs are a combination of two separate vowels. All 7 vowels can be used in monophthong form but diphthong is restricted to only a few combinations.<ref name=":1" />
=== Nouns === Nouns are words that can be placed in the “Subject” or “Object” portions of a sentence and can be modified for possessive relations. There are 3 functions of noun phrases: semantic function, pragmatic function, and grammatical function. In Irarutu, the grammatical function for nouns and pronouns do not differ for unique situations.<ref name=":1" />
==== Possessive Noun Phrase ====
For possessive noun phrase there are usually no prefixes, suffixes, or any other alterations made to the noun of interest. The only cases where changes to the word are made are for body parts, names, and one's child.<ref name=":0" />
=== Verbs === Both transitive and intransitive verbs are found in the Irarutu language. These verbs are conjoined with prefixed marks to show who is creating/causing the action. Up to three unique individuals can be indicated using these marks. Sounds within the verb can change if the verb stem begins with "t, ɪ, b, m, or s.<ref name=":0" />
==== Verb Function ====
There are three different types of prefixes relating the person who is creating the action. “a-“ refers to 1st person, “m-“ for 2nd and “n-“ for 3rd. “a-“ is used for 1st person cases but holds many rules along with it. “m-“ is seen in almost all cases for a 2nd person sentence and is sometimes accompanied by an inflection. “n-“ is present with a verb root in 3rd person and also tends to use inflection in the prefix.<ref name=":1" />
=== Adjectives === Adjectives can be used to alter nouns or clauses and in most cases come after the statement it is altering. In Irarutu there is also a subclass of adjectives which differentiate the level of magnitude on which the adjective affects the subject/object. There are both clause-level and phrase-level adjectives, each of which affect the topic at hand differently. Nouns with multiple adjectives are indeed possible, but a bit uncommon. Adverbs exist but are often hard to point out in Irarutu sentence structure. Sometimes an entire phrase will be used to modify a verb or adjective. To make the meaning of a sentence clear, specific verbs, which can only be modified by certain adverbs, are used to show what part of the sentence is modifying what. The sequence and placement of the adverb also helps identify which part of the claim it is modifying.<ref name=":1" />

'''Jacqui (Jacob) Eli Safra''' (*1948, alias: '''J.E. Beaucaire''') is a [[millionaire]] Brazilian [[investor]] from [[Geneva]]<ref>[[:he:יעקב (ז'אקי) ספרא]]</ref>{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=November 2017}}. He is a descendant of the [[Syria|Syrian]]-[[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Jew]]ish Safra banking family.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robert Kolker|title=Shadows And Fog|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/movies/features/6134/|accessdate=6 November 2013|newspaper=New York Magazine}}</ref>
==Biography== Jacqui Eli Safra is the son of Elie Safra (1922 - 1993) and Yvette Dabbah (1927 - 2006) and the nephew of [[Edmond Safra]]. He is a graduate of the [[Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania]] and worked in various positions at the [[Republic National Bank]] of [[New York City|New York]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Charles Lyons|title=Safra: Woody’s claim lame|url=https://variety.com/2002/biz/news/safra-woody-s-claim-lame-1117868102/|accessdate=21 March 2016|newspaper=Variety}}</ref>
Some of Safra's investments include:<ref>{{cite news|last=Unknown|title=Chateau Chevalier in the spotlight: Jacqui Safra|url=https://www.goldmedalwineclub.com/media/gm/user/gmwc/img/newsletters/barkingdog_chateauchevalier_v25i04.pdf|accessdate=21 March 2016|newspaper=Gold Series Wine Press|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907060906/https://www.goldmedalwineclub.com/media/gm/user/gmwc/img/newsletters/barkingdog_chateauchevalier_v25i04.pdf|archivedate=7 September 2015|df=}}</ref> *''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]''; *''[[Merriam-Webster]]''; *''[[Spring Mountain Vineyard]]'' ([[Saint Helena, California]]); *''Parknasilla Hotel'' and neighbouring ''[[Garinish Island (County Kerry)|Garinish Island]]'' (both near [[Sneem]], [[County Kerry]], [[Republic of Ireland]]).<ref>http://www.irishexaminer.com/property/commercial/sheen-falls-poised-for-sale-219103.html</ref><ref>http://www.irishexaminer.com/business/parknasilla-hotel-revenues-likely-to-rise-by-6-450262.html</ref>
==Filmography== Under the name '''J.E. Beaucaire''' (the name of the character played by [[Bob Hope]] in the film ''[[Monsieur Beaucaire (1946 film)|Monsieur Beaucaire]]''), Safra appeared in minor roles in three movies and financed eight [[Woody Allen]] films through a production company, Sweetland Films, run with girlfriend [[Jean Doumanian]], a close friend of Allen.<ref>{{cite news|last=Calderone|first=Michael|title=Jaqui Safra Asks $50 Million For East Side House|url=http://observer.com/2005/10/jaqui-safra-asks-50-million-for-east-side-house/|accessdate=6 November 2013|newspaper=New York Observer}}</ref>

The '''Kurtey people''' (var. '''Kourtey''') are a small ethnic group found along the [[Niger River]] valley in parts of the [[West African]] nations of [[Niger]], [[Benin]], [[Mali]], and [[Nigeria]]. They are also found in considerable numbers in [[Ghana]], [[Togo]], [[Ivory Coast]], and [[Burkina Faso]]. ==Assimilation into Songhai== The Kurtey were formed from the movement of [[Fula people]] into the Niger River valley of modern [[Tillaberi Region]], Niger in the 18th century, and their intermarriage with local [[Songhai people|Songhai]], [[Zarma people|Zarma]], [[Sorko people|Sorko]] and others.<ref name="Decalo1997">{{Cite book |last=Decalo |first=Samuel |title=Historical Dictionary of the Niger (3rd ed.) |publisher=Scarecrow Press|location=Boston & Folkestone |year=1997 |isbn=0-8108-3136-8 }}{{rp|pp. 191-192}}</ref> While retaining many aspects of Fula traditional culture, the Kurtey have assimilated into Songhai-Zarma ways of life and speak a Southern Songhay dialect.<ref name=SIL1997>Harrison, Byron, Annette Harrison, and Michael J. Rueck, with Mahaman Soumana as Interpreter. [http://www.sil.org/silesr/1999/004/zarmarpt4.pdf "Southern Songhay Speech Varieties in Niger: A Sociolinguistic Survey of the Zarma, Songhay, Kurtey, Wogo, and Dendi Peoples of Niger."] (1997).</ref> Some outside observers consider them a subsection of the Songhai people,<ref>[http://www.unhcr.org/refworld/docid/4954ce61c.html Minority Rights Group International, World Directory of Minorities and Indigenous Peoples - Niger : Overview], July 2008. Online. UNHCR Refworld, [accessed 8 April 2009]</ref> while others describe them as communities with distinct histories, cultures, and ethnic self-identification within the larger Songhai speaking social space, of which the [[Songhai people]] are only one part.<ref>[[Paul Stoller]]. pp.94-5 in [http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/hom_0439-4216_1984_num_24_3_368516?_Prescripts_Search_tabs1=standard& Eye, Mind and Word in Anthropology]. L'Homme (1984) Volume 24 Issue 3-4 pp.91-114.</ref>
==Customs and demography== They today number less than 50000, concentrated on islands and along the Niger river banks near [[Sansani]], [[Dessa]] and [[Ayorou]]; in [[Niamey]] (especially in [[Koutoukalé]] quarter); and in villages along the lower middle Niger from Gao to northern Nigeria.<ref name="Decalo1997" /> Some Kurtey continue to mark themselves with their traditional facial scarification: a small cross at the top of each cheekbone.<ref>Paul Stoller and Cheryl Olkes. In sorcery's shadow : a memoir of apprenticeship among the Songhay of Niger. Chicago : University of Chicago Press, (1987). {{ISBN|0-226-77542-9}} p.56</ref> The Kurtey are also one of six Nigerien ethnic groups who have historically carried out ritual [[Female circumcision]].<ref>[http://www.cirp.org/news/UNnetwork02-06-04/ Niger: Legal Ban On Female Circumcision Widely Ignored]. UN Integrated Regional Information Networks, 6 February 2004. According to this UN report, these groups are the [[Fula people|Fula]] ({{lang-fr|Peul}} or {{lang|fr|Peulh}}; {{lang-ff|Fulɓe}}), [[Gourmantche]], [[Zarma people|Djerma]]-[[Songhai people|Songhai]], [[Kurtey]], [[Wogo people]] and [[Diffa Arabs|Arabs]].</ref> Kurtey traditionally engage in sedentary cattle raising -- a legacy of their Fula ancestry -- as well as fishing (like [[Sorko people]]), [[tobacco]] farming, and riverine flood irrigated [[millet]] and [[rice]] farming.<ref name="Decalo1997" />
==Relations with others== In the 19th century, many Muslim Kurtey engaged in slave raiding amongst pagan Zarma along the Niger,<ref name=OdS1970>Jean-Pierre Olivier de Sardan. [http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/jafr_0037-9166_1970_num_40_2_1966 Remarques sur la notion de «captif» (à propos des Wogo et Kurtey du Niger)]. Journal de la Société des Africanistes. (1970) Volume 40, Issue 40-2, pp. 171-174</ref> earning them the Zarma nickname "Thieves of Men"<ref> Jean Pierre Olivier de Sardan. Les voleurs d’hommes (notes sur l’histoire des Kurtey). Etudes Nigériennes no. 25. IFAN-CNRSH: Paris-Niamey (1969)</ref> While historically bitter rivals of the [[Wogo people]] who settled in the same area from the middle Niger beginning around 1800, the two ethnic groups have become closely related, settled in the same areas, speaking similar dialects, and sharing similar ways of life. Both were [[Muslim]] before migrating to the area, enjoying close relations with the Fula [[Emirite of Say]].<ref name=SIL1997 />
==References== {{Reflist}} *Paul Stoller. The Negotiation of Songhay Space: Phenomenology in the Heart of Darkness. American Ethnologist, Vol. 7, No. 3 (Aug., 1980), pp. 419-431 *Jibrin Ibrahim. Political Exclusion, Democratization and Dynamics of Ethnicity in Niger. Africa Today, Vol. 41, No. 3, Electoral Successes: Harbingers of Hope? (3rd Qtr., 1994), pp. 15-39
==Further reading== *{{cite book | last = Jean-Pierre | first = Olivier de Sardan | title = Les Societes Songhay-Zarma, Niger-Mali: Chefs, Guerriers, Esclaves, Paysans-- | publisher = Editions Karthala | location = Paris | year = 1984 | isbn = 978-2-86537-106-8 }}
